fr:title.text: Elementary linear group is a subgroup of special linear group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Elementary linear group is a subgroup of special linear group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a unital associative commutative ring, let n be a natural number. Then \mathrm {EL}_{n}(R) is a subgroup of \mathrm {SL}_{n}(R).

The determinant of each generator for the elementary linear group is \det (I+rE_{ij})=1, which means that the generating set for \mathrm {EL}_{n}(R) is a subset of \mathrm {SL}_{n}(R). Hence the result.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The determinant is only really well-defined for matrices in \mathrm {Mat}_{n}(R) where R is a commutative ring. This is because the determinant "behaves as we expect" for matrices over commutative rings.
There are ways to generalize to noncommutative rings, but it depends on how "nice" the ring is.

For example, over the quaternions, we can define \mathrm {SL}_{n}(\mathbb {H}) since we can embed \mathrm {Mat}_{n}(\mathbb {H}) as a real subalgebra of \mathrm {Mat}_{2n}(\mathbb {C}). Then the unit group of this subalgebra is defined to be the general linear group \mathrm {GL}_{n}(\mathbb {H}).
But for, say, the Octonions, we run into difficulties. See Petyt's "The special linear group for nonassociative rings".

fr:title.text: Special linear group over commutative rings

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Special linear group over commutative rings

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a commutative ring. We define the Special Linear Group over R to be the group \mathrm {SL}_{n}(R) = \{g\in \mathrm {GL}_{n}(R)\mid \det (g)=1\}. That is to say, it is the kernel of the determinant homomorphism.

fr:title.text: Baez-ian Special linear group over the octonions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Baez-ian Special linear group over the octonions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: There are several different ways to construct a group over the Octonions analogous to the special linear group.

Let R be a (possibly nonassociative) ring (possibly nonunital). If E_{i,j} is the n\times n matrix which is 1 at row i and column j, but zero everywhere else, then we define the group \mathrm {SL}_{n}(R) = \langle L_{I+aE_{i,j}}\mid a\in R, 1\leq i\neq j\leq n\rangle to be generated by multiplying on the left by I+aE_{i,j}.

For alternative algebras, this means L_{E_{i}}L_{E_{i}}=L_{E_{i}^{2}}=\pm 1 and for E_{i}\neq E_{j}, using the associator [z,w,u]=(zw)u-z(wu) we have: 0=[E_{i},E_{j},z] + [E_{j},E_{i},z] = L_{E_{i}E_{j}+E_{j}E_{i}}(z)-(L_{E_{i}}L_{E_{j}}+L_{E_{j}}L_{E_{i}})(z), and hence: L_{E_{i}}L_{E_{j}}=-L_{E_{j}}L_{E_{i}}. Using this, we have a precise, unambiguous ordering to the product of elements of the group.

fr:title.text: Left (and right) multiplication as a matrix

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Left (and right) multiplication as a matrix

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Consider a couple quaternions X=x + y\mathbf {i} + z\mathbf {j} + w\mathbf {k} and Y = a + b\mathbf {i} + c\mathbf {j} + d\mathbf {k}. Then we have L_{X}(Y) correspond to:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: L_{X}(Y) = \begin {pmatrix}x & -y & -z & -w\\ y & x & -w & z\\ z & w & x & -y\\ w & -z & y & x \end {pmatrix}\begin {pmatrix}a\\ b\\ c\\ d\end {pmatrix}
fr:mainmatter.html:p: Similarly, we have R_{Y}(X) correspond to:
fr:mainmatter.fr:tex: R_{Y}(X) = \begin {pmatrix}a & -b & -c & -d\\ b & a & d & -c\\ c & -d & a & b\\ d & c & -b & a\end {pmatrix}\begin {pmatrix}x\\ y\\ z\\ w\end {pmatrix}
fr:mainmatter.html:p: Observe, when \Vert X\Vert =1, we see L_{X} is an orthogonal matrix of real numbers (similarly, when \Vert Y\Vert =1, we see R_{Y} is an orthogonal matrix of real numbers).
More generally, in a composition algebra \mathbb {K}, any unit u\in \mathbb {K} (i.e., element with \Vert u\Vert =1) has L_{u} and R_{u} both be orthogonal matrices.

fr:title.text: Baez-ian Special Linear Algebra for n\geq 3

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Baez-ian Special Linear Algebra for n\geq 3

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let R be a commutative unital associative ring. Let A be a finite-dimensional algebra over R that is free as an R-module (and have a basis e_{1}, …, e_{m}).

Write \mathfrak {M}_{A} for the left multiplication algebra of A; i.e., \mathfrak {M}_{A} is the R-algebra generated by \{L_{re_{i}}\mid r\in R\}. Since A is free over R, we have \mathfrak {M}_{A}\subseteq \mathrm {End}_{R}(R^{m})=M_{m}(R).

Under these assumptions, if n\geq 3, then \mathfrak {sl}_{n}(A)\cong \{x\in \mathrm {Mat}_{n}(\mathfrak {M}_{A})\mid \mathrm {tr}(x)\in [\mathfrak {M}_{A},\mathfrak {M}_{A}]\}. In particular, \mathfrak {sl}_{n}(A)\subseteq \mathfrak {sl}_{mn}(R).

fr:title.text: Derived subgroup of general linear group

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Derived subgroup of general linear group

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We can relate the commutator subgroup of \mathrm {GL}_{n}(R) to \mathrm {SL}_{n}(R) under certain circumstances on n and R. For skew-fields, the derived subgroup is equal to the elementary linear group.

html:li.html:p: Let R be a unital ring of finite stable rank \mathrm {sr}(R). Then for every n>\mathrm {sr}(R) we have [\mathrm {GL}_{n}(R),\mathrm {GL}_{n}(R)]=\mathrm {EL}_{n}(R).
This follows from Vaserstein's injective stability theorem (theorem 10.15 in B. Magurn, An Algebraic Introduction to K-Theory, CUP, 2002).

Bass proved this is true for any (associative) unital ring R when n\geq 3. See arXiv:1510.07143. Further when R is commutative, n=1 has [\mathrm {GL}_{1}(R),\mathrm {GL}_{1}(R)]=\mathrm {EL}_{1}(R). For more about the n=2 case, see Cohn's "On the structure of the \mathrm {GL}_{2} of a ring".
In particular, for any field \mathbb {F}, we have [\mathrm {GL}_{n}(\mathbb {F}),\mathrm {GL}_{n}(\mathbb {F})]=\mathrm {EL}_{n}(\mathbb {F}) when either n\neq 2 or \mathbb {F}\neq \mathbb {F}_{2}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p:
A (Unital) Ring consists of a set R equipped with
an Abelian group structure (R,+,0), and
a multiplication \star \colon R\times R\to R, and
(Optional) a "one" element 1\in R such that for any a,b,c\in R,
Associativity of addition: a+(b+c)=(a+b)+c
Additive identity element: a+0=0+a=a
Additive inverse: a+(-a)=0
Commutativity of addition: a+b=b+a
(Optional) Associativity of multiplication: a\star (b\star c)=(a\star b)\star c
(Optional) Unital property (i.e., multiplicative identity element): a\star 1=1\star a=a
Left distributivity of multiplication over addition: a\star (b+c)=(a\star b)+(a\star c)
Right distributivity of multiplication over addition (a+b)\star c=(a\star c)+(b\star c) Some rings don't have a multiplicative unit 1, in which case they are "nonunital rings". If we don't care about the existence of the multiplicative unit, we'll just speak of "rings".

We also don't require all rings to be associative (i.e., multiplication may or may not be associative). When it matters, we will speak of "associative rings" and "nonassociative rings", but by default we will assume rings as associative.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: We could define a unital ring as an Abelian group equipped with a monoid structure. The axioms for a unital ring would be satisfied automatically.
